persona.name: Rafael Julian Crowe

occupation.title: Self-employed / Freelance Graphic Designer and Part-time Online Reseller
occupation.organization: Independent — clients include local small businesses, food trucks, church groups, and online marketplaces (Etsy/Poshmark/eBay)
occupation.description: Rafael runs his own small creative services gig. He designs logos, social media graphics, inexpensive flyers and menus for local mom-and-pop restaurants, and occasionally builds simple landing pages. He balances client work with reselling secondhand clothing and small home goods on marketplaces to supplement income. Responsibilities include client communication, creative mockups in Adobe Creative Cloud, basic web maintenance, order fulfillment for his reselling business, simple bookkeeping, invoicing, and scheduling. He advertises via social media and word-of-mouth. Skills on the job emphasize quick turnaround, visual sense, practical marketing, pricing under tight budgets, and negotiating with clients who are also budget-conscious. Typical challenges: cash-flow variability, late payments from clients, balancing client work with childcare, limited time for marketing or skill-deepening courses, and keeping software/hardware current on a tight budget. He occasionally picks up part-time day shifts doing installations or event setup for a local small event company when extra cash is needed.

persona.education: High school diploma from a public school in Jacksonville. Completed community college coursework in graphic design and small business management (about 2 years), earned several industry short courses and certificates (Adobe Certified Associate, Google Ads fundamentals), but did not complete a bachelor's degree due to needing to work full time and start a family.
long_term_goals: Provide financial stability and a modest home equity for his family so his children can have better opportunities than he did.
Build his freelance/side business into a dependable local creative services shop that can bring in steady part-time income and possibly employ one assistant within five years.
Be present and emotionally available for his children through the early formative years while also carving out time for his own interests (tech, music).
Create a small emergency fund (3 months' expenses) and start contributing regularly to retirement accounts once cashflow steadies.
Teach his children bilingual Spanish-English basics and maintain cultural traditions from his Puerto Rican/Cuban family side.
Be an involved member of his local community—school PTA, church group or neighborhood association—once schedule allows.
persona.style: Warm, conversational Southern/Caribbean-influenced English with a light Jacksonville urban accent; frequently code-switches into casual Spanish when speaking to family or some neighbors. Speaks in short, concrete sentences when busy, more reflective and loquacious when relaxed or talking about family and music. Mannerisms include a quick, self-deprecating chuckle, habitual rubbing of his left eyebrow when thinking, and snapping his fingers to get his children's attention in public. He prefers comfortable, practical clothing — worn sneakers, graphic tees, light button-downs — but will tidy up for church events or school functions. Uses hand gestures when telling stories; often pulls out his phone to show images or receipts. Polite but blunt with service providers; negotiates prices and asks pointed questions. Uses humor to defuse tension and is prone to using pop-culture references (90s rap, reggaetón, and Latin pop) in everyday conversation. When stressed his speech accelerates and he intersperses Spanish phrases. He often speaks in terms of 'we' for family decisions, reflective of a collaborative home style with his spouse.

traits: Devoted family man who places children's needs high on his priority list.
Pragmatic and resourceful — finds workarounds when budgets are tight.
Distrustful of large institutions and mainstream media; prefers peer networks and local advice.
Populist/anti-establishment orientation — skeptical of political elites and disconnected technocrats.
Entrepreneurial and opportunistic — quick to try a side-hustle or new app that promises income.
Emotionally open with close friends and family, guarded with strangers.
Witty and playful with sarcasm; uses humor to manage stress.
Struggles with anxiety around money and stability; occasionally frets about debt and bills.
Values practical skills over credentials; proud of being self-taught in many areas.
Socially warm but selective — enjoys neighborhood block parties and small gatherings; dislikes large formal events.
Resilient and persistent: when problems arise he tries many small fixes rather than waiting for perfect solutions.
Occasionally stubborn and contrarian in conversations, especially about politics and economics.

big_five.openness: Medium-High. Curious about new gadgets, social media tools, and music; enjoys learning practical skills and design tricks; less interested in abstract philosophy beyond concrete implications.
big_five.conscientiousness: Medium. Able to deliver projects on time but occasionally misses deadlines when family demands spike; keeps informal systems (phone reminders, shoe-box receipts).
big_five.extraversion: Medium. Enjoys small-group socializing, neighborhood interactions, and client meetings; needs downtime after busy social days.
big_five.agreeableness: Medium. Generally cooperative and helpful with family and neighbors but quick to stand his ground on perceived unfairness (prices, politics).
big_five.neuroticism: Medium-High. Worries about money and the future, experiences periods of insomnia and stress, but recovers through social support and practical planning.

interests: Digital design (logo trends, templates, Canva alternatives).
Secondhand fashion sourcing and reselling — hunting for branded pieces on thrift trips.
Tech gadgets and early-adopter apps for small business (payment readers, scheduling apps).
Social media as a marketing tool—especially Instagram, Facebook Marketplace, and TikTok for business tips.
Latin music (reggaetón, salsa, merengue), 90s hip-hop, and occasional country songs tied to childhood.
Family outings: splash pads, inexpensive aquariums, public parks with shaded playgrounds.
DIY home fixes and small carpentry projects learned from YouTube.
Street food and local food trucks — favorite pastime on weekends.
Budget travel and destination hacks that are child-friendly.
Short podcasts on entrepreneurship, small business marketing, and parenting tips.
likes: Cheap, strong drip coffee in the morning (local corner cafe over chains).
Comfortable sneakers and breathable shirts — clothes that survive toddler messes.
Phone apps that automate tasks: invoicing apps, calendar sync, and delivery-tracking.
Brands with practical value: Samsung midrange phones, refurbished MacBook for design, affordable Echo Dot for music and timers.
Family movie nights with animated films and popcorn (adds hot sauce sometimes).
Street tacos, arroz con pollo, fried plantains and quick southern comfort foods like mac & cheese.
Local community events and block cookouts where children can run around safely.
Simple Sunday rituals — big family breakfast, park, church or community center visit.
Sales and coupon apps, loyalty cards and stacking discounts when buying kids' clothes or groceries.
Small, breathable backpacks for day trips with wipes, snacks, and a spare shirt.
Watching tutorial videos to pick up a new Photoshop trick or reselling strategy.
Limited streaming subscriptions — rotates services to watch specific shows and cancel when done.
Handmade or sentimental gifts over expensive but impersonal items.
Podcasts and YouTube channels focused on thrifting, flip reselling, and side-hustle advice.
Weather-appropriate outdoor activities: splash pads in summer, short beach visits in shoulder seasons.
Occasional adult pizza-and-beer nights with a trusted friend while spouse watches kids.
Organized chaos — likes things to have a place but tolerates visible mess for a while.
Cars with roomy back seats or fold-flat trunks for stroller and resale inventory.
Simple tools: a reliable multi-tool, a cordless drill, and a small shop vacuum.
Fast food occasionally for convenience but tries to cook at home most weeknights to save money.
dislikes: Bank fees, confusing billing, and surprise charges.
Pretentious boutique brands with inflated prices and poor durability.
Long bureaucratic phone menus and customer service hold times.
Elitist or dismissive attitudes from professionals; dislikes talking down to people without lived experience.
Expensive childcare options that promise a lot but don’t fit his budget.
Overly curated 'Instagram-perfect' parenting advice — prefers practical tips.
Loud, crowded indoor play spaces with no seating for parents.
Waste and single-use plastics when there are cheap reusable alternatives.
Mainstream news outlets he perceives as biased or disconnected from working-class reality.
Apps that require subscription fees for basic functionality; prefers freemium or one-time purchases.

vacation_preferences.general: Prefers short, low-cost family trips within driving distance. Balances child-friendly activities with occasional adult-only downtime. Plans around nap schedules and uses rental homes or small family suites to minimize cost.
how_children_fit_in: Always checks for toddler-friendly amenities: pack-and-play availability, child menus, fenced yards or secure play space.
Prioritizes shorter drives (under 3 hours) to avoid long car tantrums and to reduce lodging costs.
Chooses destinations offering value — beach public access, city parks, free local festivals, small aquariums, splash pads.
Brings a travel stroller, portable white noise machine and favorite stuffed animal to maintain routines away from home.
Involves children in light planning (let the oldest pick a park or treat) to keep them engaged and reduce meltdowns.
For adult-only short trips (rare), arranges babysitting trade with another parent or relies on an occasionally available grandparent for one-night events.
Avoids expensive theme parks unless there's a deep discount or family member pays; prefers local fairs or discounted weekday admission.
Books modest, family-friendly rentals with kitchen facilities to save on eating out.
typical_destinations: Local beaches (early morning to avoid heat and crowds).
State parks with picnic areas and short trails.
Visits to extended family households for cheap, supervised childcare and built-in meals.
Weekend drives to nearby coastal towns for one-night stays.

media_and_technology_preferences.devices: Mid-range Android phone, refurbished MacBook Air for graphic work, tablet for kids' drawing apps, inexpensive smart TV.
media_and_technology_preferences.social_platforms: Active on Facebook (local groups, Marketplace), Instagram for portfolio, TikTok for short resell tips and design reels, WhatsApp for family group chats.
media_and_technology_preferences.content_consumption: Listens to podcasts during drives and chores, watches tutorial videos late at night, follows a handful of niche creators for politics and business tips rather than mainstream anchors.
media_and_technology_preferences.shopping: Enjoys browsing thrift stores and outlet malls; shops online when there are clear savings and free returns.

beliefs: Big institutions (big banks, large news networks, and big tech) are out of touch with ordinary people's needs and often put profits before people.
Local businesses are more trustworthy than national chains because people know their neighbors and reputation matters.
Healthcare is important and affordability is a real problem; he favors incremental market-based reforms that increase transparency and competition instead of sweeping government takeovers.
Public schools should focus on basic skills and practical life prep; community involvement is crucial.
Immigration should be managed but families seeking a better life should be treated humanely; he is skeptical of elite rhetoric but sympathetic to family migrants.
Politicians are frequently self-serving; he prefers candidates who emphasize common-sense policies and accountability.
Taxes should be fair; wealth hoarding by large corporations is a problem, but he is wary of radical economic redistribution that might harm small businesses.
Small-scale co-ops and local ownership models appeal to him as a practical alternative to corporate control.
Frugality and resourcefulness are virtues—learn to fix, reuse, and resell rather than discard.
Personal responsibility matters, but society should protect families with children through sensible supports (childcare subsidies, tax credits).
Mainstream media often sensationalizes stories; he favors peer-to-peer info, local reporting, and niche outlets that feel more relevant.
Trust is earned locally: word-of-mouth recommendations from neighbors and Facebook Marketplace reviews are more persuasive than polished ads.
Technology has improved life in practical ways, but he dislikes surveillance capitalism and opaque subscription traps.
Corporations often lobby for rules that favor them; public oversight and transparency are needed.
Entry-level and vocational training should be accessible and respected; college is not the only path to a stable life.
Community churches and informal neighborhood groups can be anchors for support even for those who aren't highly religious.
Family traditions and bilingual culture are important to transmit to his kids; language retention is a concrete goal.
He worries about housing affordability in his city; hopes zoning and small-scale development can help without displacing current residents.
Crime prevention should be practical and community-driven, paired with programs for youth engagement.
He believes in second chances and practical rehabilitation for some offenders rather than purely punitive approaches.
Energy prices and utility costs are a concrete household issue; he favors diversified energy choices and consumer protections.
Small business owners should get easier access to microloans and local procurement opportunities.
Childcare and early education are critical; public-private partnerships that expand accessible slots are preferred.
He is skeptical of sweeping environmental regulations that ignore worker impacts; supports pragmatic, phased policies that create local jobs.
Vaccinations are accepted for school-aged children, but he is cautious about mandates that offer no clear choices or transparent data.
He thinks civic institutions can be reformed rather than discarded—local control with oversight appeals to him.
He values straightforward public communication and is put off by jargon and patronizing campaigns.
Consumer protections against surprise medical bills and predatory lending are essential.
He believes in building resilience through savings and local mutual aid networks rather than relying solely on government.
Parenting is both joyful and exhausting; community and family networks matter more than celebrity parenting advice.
He feels political identity is less important than pragmatic policy outcomes that affect his family's daily life (jobs, school safety, cost of living).
He is open to alternative economic arrangements like worker-owned co-ops if they prove sustainable in practice.
skills: Proficient in Adobe Photoshop, Illustrator, and basic InDesign workflows for logo and flyer design; comfortable building social media graphics templates.
Able to assemble and maintain affordable workstation hardware and troubleshoot common computer issues.
Practical HTML/CSS for simple landing pages and using templates (WordPress, Wix, Squarespace basic editing).
Experienced at running small online resale operations: photographing items, writing descriptions, pricing, shipping, and customer communications.
Basic bookkeeping for a one-person business: invoicing, expense tracking, simple spreadsheets, and using a low-cost accounting app.
Customer service skills: negotiating with clients, setting expectations, managing revisions and tight deadlines.
Can patch drywall, install shelves, basic plumbing fixes (toilet flapper, faucet washers), and use a cordless drill safely.
Bilingual Spanish-English conversational fluency — can translate everyday documents and speak with Spanish-speaking clients or family.
Time management under competing demands: batch working in the morning/evening to fit around childcare.
Basic photography skills for product shots and social media content.
Negotiation skills for buying bulk inventory at thrift stores or flea markets.
Childcare and toddler soothing techniques learned through hands-on parenting (nap routines, distraction, safe babyproofing).

general: Checks phone constantly for client messages, marketplace offers, and neighborhood group chats; often replies quickly to customer inquiries.
Snacks throughout the day—chips, cookies, and fruit—particularly late at night while working on design jobs.
Uses social media both for business promotion and to decompress (memes, short videos).
Uses a habit of doing quick '10-minute cleanups' before guests arrive; tolerates a certain level of clutter.
Negotiates prices at thrift stores and will walk away if a seller asks too much.
Reads customer reviews thoroughly before trying a new software or service.
Prefers hands-on learning — watches YouTube tutorials and follows step-by-step guides.
Relies on a few trusted friends for trades: babysitting swaps, skill exchanges, and shared rides when needed.

morning: Wakes between 6:00–7:00 AM depending on the children's needs.
Prepares coffee, dresses quickly, and helps with breakfast and getting the children ready for daycare/relative drop-off if arranged that day.
Checks invoices and messages for urgent client work before dropping kids off or starting the day.
Does a 20–30 minute focused work session in the late morning (client revisions, listings) when children are at care.
workday: Alternates between client jobs, reselling tasks, and household errands; takes calls in the car occasionally when stuck in traffic.
Breaks work into 60–90 minute sprints with deliberate pauses for childcare or errands.
Runs quick local errands (grocery pickup, thrift run) mid-afternoon when clients are less active.
If doing event setup shifts, will arrange childcare in advance and adjust delivery windows accordingly.
evening: Prepares a simple family dinner (rice/beans/pan-fried protein) and eats together when possible.
Bath and bedtime routines are shared responsibilities; Rafael often handles story time and lullabies.
After kids' bedtime he does an extra work sprint (1–2 hours) or catches up on industry tutorials.
Often falls asleep late (after midnight) due to screen time and catch-up work.
weekend: Saturdays: thrift runs, market listings, church or community event in the morning, park in the afternoon.
Sundays: larger family meal, occasional visit to extended family for help or socializing, and prepping client work for the week.
Occasional night out with spouse every few months when a babysitter, family member or babysit-swap is available.

physical.general: Overall functional but not athletic. Slightly overweight (BMI in the overweight range). Low engagement in formal exercise routines. Has seasonal allergies and occasional back stiffness from long hours on a cheap chair.
conditions: Mild seasonal allergic rhinitis (uses antihistamines as needed).
Occasional low back pain from bending and lifting during reselling and home projects.
No major chronic diseases diagnosed (no diabetes, no heart disease reported).
physical.preventive: Infrequent preventive care due to costs and schedule; dental care is irregular (visits when problems arise).
physical.sleep: Insufficient sleep is common—typically 5–6 hours most nights, occasionally worse during peak work/family stress. Experiences daytime tiredness.
physical.substance_use: Occasional beer on nights off; no heavy drinking. Non-smoker.

mental.status: Moderate stress and anxiety around finances and juggling roles. Uses humor and social contact to cope. Has not engaged in long-term therapy but would consider it if affordable and child-friendly.
mental.access: Limited mental health support due to cost and scheduling, prefers community resources or employer EAP if ever available.

relationships.name: Mariana Crowe
relationships.description: Mariana works part-time at a pediatric clinic's front desk and manages much of the household scheduling. She is originally Cuban-American, bilingual, practical, and the family’s emotional anchor. The marriage is cooperative, sometimes tense over money but generally affectionate and team-oriented. They share parenting duties; Mariana prefers more structure while Rafael is more improvisational.

relationships.name: Mateo Crowe
relationships.description: Outgoing, energetic, loves building blocks, basic Spanish songs, and playing at the splash pad. Enrolled part-time in a church-affiliated preschool two mornings a week.

relationships.name: Isla Crowe
relationships.description: Curious toddler who loves to be held and explores textures. Still napping once or twice a day; family is trying to settle her into consistent bedtime rituals.

relationships.name: Lucia (mother-in-law)
relationships.description: Lives nearby and is bilingual. Provides occasional childcare and cooks shared meals on Sundays. Trusted source for cultural and child-rearing advice.
relationships.support_frequency: Irregular but crucial when available — helps with babysitting occasionally but is not reliable enough for full-time care.

relationships.name: Thomas Crowe
relationships.description: Rafael's father, white, retired factory worker living in a nearby small town. Practical, not very demonstrative, offers carpentry help and occasionally lends a small amount of money when asked.
A core group of 3–4 neighborhood dads who swap babysitting, tools, and gig-work leads. Friends include a former coworker who does event setup and a fellow reseller who shares sourcing tips.
A loose network of small business clients, a local cafe owner who often needs flyers, and a church bulletin coordinator who is a frequent referrer.

other_facts: Was born in Jacksonville to a mixed household; maternal grandparents emigrated from Puerto Rico, paternal family is multi-generational southern white. This mix shaped his bilingual upbringing and taste in food and music.
Chose the middle name 'Julian' from his mother's favorite uncle; keeps photos of extended family in a living-room picture frame.
Dropped out of a community college certificate program temporarily to help support his sister during a health scare.
First side-hustle was purchasing and flipping broken electronics he repaired in his garage; that taught him basics of e-commerce and margins.
Learned to cook basic family recipes from his mother and mother-in-law; arroz con pollo and slow-simmered beans are weekend staples.
Remembers a childhood summer when the family lived with cousins for several months after a hurricane — formed a belief in local mutual aid and community reliance.
Has a small tattoo on his left forearm: a minimalist wave and palm tree as a reminder of calm and family beach days.
Once designed a logo for a local food-truck that later became a regular client and referred three other small businesses.
Has a mild fear of being judged for not having a college degree despite having marketable skills and steady income streams.
Keeps a shoebox with receipts, customer notes and a few small mementos like his son's first tooth and old concert tickets.
His favorite childhood memory is fishing off a small pier with his grandfather; tries to recreate a simplified version for his kids now.
Tried therapy once after a messy argument with Mariana; stopped because of scheduling and cost, but found the experience helpful and would consider again if accessible.
Uses a strict mental rule: if a purchase is over $200, wait 48 hours and assess if it's necessary (this came after a regretted gadget purchase).
Has a small, slightly battered acoustic guitar he plays for his kids at bedtime; knows a handful of lullabies and simple chords.
Volunteers occasionally at church-run food drives and a neighborhood clean-up day, mostly because it's practical help that fits his schedule.
Once had a nearly successful Kickstarter idea for a low-cost kids' activity kit but couldn't fulfill due to supply chain and time constraints; still regrets not following through.
His favorite childhood foods influence his approach to feeding kids — he blends Latin and Southern tastes (plantains with mac & cheese occasionally).
Owns a small set of tools he inherited from his father and takes pride in being the 'fix-it' neighbor for appliance belts and loose hinges.
Was briefly homeless for a few weeks in his early twenties after a job loss; that experience cemented frugality and distrust of unstable employment.
Keeps a one-paragraph personal mission note on his fridge about 'being present and teaching his kids to be curious and kind', written in a moment of clarity years ago.
Once drove overnight to pick up a bulk clothing lot he bought as a reseller; the gamble paid off and funded a month of groceries.
Holds a small emergency cash stash hidden in a book at home (enough for a week's groceries) — learned the habit from his grandmother.
Has a running joke with Mariana about their 'split-shift parenting' where one naps, the other works; both laugh but it's a real coping mechanism.
Is proud of a single framed review from a client stuck on his wall — 'saved our small business with timely, affordable design' — which he shows when motivation lags.
Keeps a 'no phones at dinner' rule on most weeknights to preserve family time, though exceptions occur when fulfilling urgent client needs.
Is allergic to cats but grew up with them; their presence at family gatherings is tolerated but he keeps antihistamines handy.
Has a dated but reliable van with a leaky driver-side window used for hauling resale inventory and kids to parks; plans to replace it when finances allow.
Had an intense week once when both kids were sick and a major client demanded rework; the stress triggered a small physical panic episode which resolved after help from Mariana and a neighbor.
Finds personal meaning in small rituals: Sunday breakfast together, a five-minute bedtime reflection with each child, and swapping daily 'one good thing' at dinner.
Believes in celebrating small wins publicly on social media (like landing a client or selling a tricky item) because it builds credibility and morale.
Once mentored a teen at a local community center on basic design and reselling; the experience reminded him why vocational pathways are valuable.
Has a collection of mixtapes and playlists he curates for different moods: 'work hustle', 'Sunday family', and 'late-night learning'.
Is working toward the small goal of owning a basic business liability insurance policy to protect his freelance work once cash allows.
Trusts a small circle of advisors (two friends, his mother-in-law) for big financial decisions; avoids large financial institutions for guidance unless necessary.
Keeps a mental list of fallback jobs (event setup, delivery driving) he can do for short-term cash if client work dips suddenly.
Values hands-on parenting memories over expensive purchases — would choose a DIY backyard fort day over buying costly toys when possible.
